value: caption=Lake Te Anau and the Murchison Mountains

is a small town on the shore of Lake Te Anau, in the

highway just north of Lumsden onto SH94. Te Anau also has an airstrip for light sightseeing aircraft.

Most travellers use Te Anau as a jumping-off point to
. Allow 2 hours to reach Milford Sound from Te Anau. There are lots of scenic stops along the way, but not much else, so stop at Fresh Choice for snacks and

value: be sure to fill up your gas tank

, as there is limited petrol available in Milford Sound.

value: , found in Te Anau Wildlife Centre and in the Murchison Mountains (across the lake from Te Anau)

content=A boat trip and guided tour into the Aurora Caves system by walking path and small boats within the cave itself where you will see thousands of glow worms. The caves are only accessible by boat, and Real Journeys operates a quality catamaran for a 30 minute cruise each way. You'll spend approximately 35min underground, where you will see some spectacular underground waterfalls, some high ceilings, and many other interesting things with a professional guide. Suitable for everyone except infants. Be aware you will need to bend over considerably at the entrance, only 1m high for 3-4m. Promotions often apply.

content="The cave of swirling water", it is the second-largest lake by surface area in New Zealand (after Lake Taupo) and the largest in the South Island. North Fiord, Middle Fiord and South Fiord are the only inland NZ fiords.
content=Off Hollyford Road on the way to Milford lies one of the most beautiful places on earth.
content=On the lakefront, paintings of the deer hunting glory days.

content=Night Sky Safaris. Fiordland may have one of the lowest levels of light pollution in the world for an unbelievable view of the night sky. Each guest gets their own binoculars during the safari, a maximum group size of 8 share a high powered telescope, and Richard uses a really cool star pointer. Highly informative and interesting, but dress warmly! c. 1.5h.
directions=1km (c. 10min walk) from the Fiordland National Park Visitor Centre towards Manapouri

content=Only a short walk from downtown, the Te Anau Wildlife Centre provides the unique opportunity to view some of New Zealand's rarest endangered birds. Be sure to see the takahe, a large flightless bird with beautiful blue plumage and an enormous red beak. With only 225 takahe left in New Zealand, this is perhaps your only opportunity to see this majestic bird.

Tramp any of the many tracks located in the area. Te Anau isn't called the walking capital of the world for no reason! The major tracks that can be started from the surrounding area include: the Kepler Track,

- all of them "Great Walks".

Don't miss out on going to

, taking a cruise, and enjoying the scenic wonderland. For once it's probably better to take a bus, they don't rush it and you get good quality commentary. 

Take a day walk somewhere - Lake Marian for example. If you don't have gear, you can hire it from Bev's Tramping Gear Hire.

value: content=Relax on a boutique cruise to the South Fiord of Lake Te Anau. Join Peter, your personal Skipper/Guide, on a gentle bush/nature walk to discover the Hidden Lakes.
content=Buy and rent DVDs, video games, and CDs, but a terrible selection of used books. Friendly staff.
content=Buy or hire most tramping gear you may need for one of the nearby tracks.

There are several decent places to eat, considering the size of Te Anau.

value: content= For pizza, pasta and both Italian & NZ wines.
content=A van parked along the Lake Te Anau lakefront which has the best fish and chips in town.
content=Specialist pie shop that has a range of fresh pies as well as sandwiches, cake slices and other treats, and great coffee, all to take away. The pies are packed with meat.
content=Serves food and drink. Warm atmosphere, cozy pub-feel and the rustic small-town kindly atmosphere you would expect in NZ.
content=Country-style cafe open for breakfast and brunch.

The local supermarket is a cheap alternative if you're self-catering.

value: content=Te Anau's main supermarket, also the best place to buy beer and wine.

The three main venues in Te Anau are The Ranch, The Moose and Redcliff, in order of the age groups most likely to be found at each location. There is also a working men's club for the older generations.
During December and January, bookings are essential! While bed and breakfasts, hotels, and backpackers abound in Te Anau, they will fill up and the nearest accommodation could be as far away as Gore.

value: content=Just outside the township overlooking a deer farm and a mighty fine view of the sunset when nature treats you right.
content=Pretty close to the town centre, doubles with a shared common area for $78, dorm beds from $28.
content=90 bed hostel in the town centre.
content=Clean and modern motel by the lakeside, with great service.
content=Good self-sufficient units and helpful owners.
content=A quirky pioneer-styled hotel, with an attached restaurant. Internet for $5/day

content=Free internet. You can use their 5 computers for up to 30 minutes for free or you can use their wireless room for unlimited wireless access for free. Follow the rules and use the designated internet room; the librarians are grumpy! Open 9am-6pm most days, 11-2 Saturdays, 1-6 Mondays, closed Sunday.

, 120 km to the north.  Milford Sound is a major tourist attraction, but the trip itself is just as spectacular and should not be rushed. There are several scenic stops along the route that provide unique views. With about 2,500 visitors a day travelling to Milford Sound at peak times, it pays to get an early start, especially as parking space sometimes runs out in the (free) Milford car parks in the late morning.
